abstracts.cdata!:
The Road Maintenance Program (Phase two)
            Project is not expected to cause land acquisition, nor
            resettlement. However, minor infrastructure, or the use of
            some areas as deposits, may result in unexpected low-level
            impacts to parcels of land or buildings, and, road
            maintenance activities may require the temporary occupation
            of plots, potentially causing crops, and income losses to
            settlers along the roads. Nonetheless, the project has been
            assigned an environmental category B. Therefore mitigation
            measures include: the need for setting design standards as
            appropriate for road, traffic, and terrain. This should
            further include an appropriate number of bridges and
            culverts, taking into consideration widening of only one
            side of existing roads, so as to retain trees. Areas where
            roads may affect wildlife, forests, or cultural heritage
            sites, should be avoided as possible in the engineering
            design, and, include protective barriers as needed.
            Moreover, the design shall include restrictions and safety
            warning signs, safe crossings and fences to control
            livestock as necessary. Drainage systems shall be adequately
            designed to control hydrological regimes, potential
            flooding, and irrigation systems, as well as to prevent soil
            erosion, and, in addition septic tanks, and solid waste
            disposal systems should be installed. Adequate wastewater
            treatment facilities should be installed at service areas,
            to prevent water contamination, while air pollution control
            measures shall include regular spraying of construction
            areas, and vegetative propagation to abate as possible dust emissions.
